characters: CLAY, VIRGE, EUGENE, JACK, RASCAL AND DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A football game is in progress. Six guys on each side, all in their late teens and early twenties, wearing khaki pants, work shirts, T-shirts. OVER, we hear the voice of BRUCE DERRINGER. The first player we see is VIRGE HOOGESTEGER.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Virge Hoogesteger., What kind of name is that? Nicknamed 'The Virgin.â€™ Well, look at him. Poor kid probably tries to get a girl into bed and she wants to make him brush his teeth and wash behind his ears. Then we see JACK BOCCI bulldozing down one of the defense players.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Look at this goon. Jack Bocci from Brooklyn. He's a magician. Wants to be the next Houdini. Well, he's escaped twenty-four missions. Not bad for an amateur. Next, EUGENE McVEY nervously making a play.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the religious one. There's always a religious one. Eugene McVey. Nineteen from Cleveland. There's always one from Cleveland. High strung, nervous, always coming down with something. How'd he get in this bunch? Next, we see RICHARD "RASCAL" MOORE showing off.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Rascal? That can't be his real name. Here we go. Richard Moore, but called the Rascal. Thinks he's a real ladies man. Talks dirty, the whole bit. Well, he'll grow out of it. If he grows at all. Then we see CLAY BUSBY, cooly running with the ball. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Clay Busby, a farmer's son from Louisiana. Plays piano and sings. Listen to this. Learned piano in a New Orleans whorehouse. Better keep that out of the papers. Last, we see DANNY DALY. He has the ball and is going for the touchdown as his team urges him on.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh boy, this kid couldn't be more Irish if he tried. Even his name, Danny Daly. He's the intellectual. Writes poetry. Likes to read. Hates sports. Danny makes the touchdown. He shouts with exhilaration and raises the ball in triumph. Just then, a huge olive drab B-17 bomber appears out of nowhere and roars directly overhead. The game is forgotten and everyone starts running towards a short, boxy control tower. Now we see that the football field is a grassy area on the side of an air field with three intersecting runways. Men are coming from all over the base, on foot and bicycle, shouting out the number of planes: five, seven, nine, twelve! Planes are appearing all over the sky.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Fifteen, sixteen!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How many went out?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Twenty-one.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: There's another! We MOVE UP TO the control tower. The balcony is crowded with men. THROUGH the window we see the CO (Commanding Officer) on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CO is in his early thirties, impeccably-dressed. He's in charge and handles his many responsibilities efficiently -- no detail is too small. In the b.g. are the adjutant and other personnel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: co Sir, they're still coming in. How can I promise you 24 planes tomorrow when they're not even back? The adjutant comes up to him with some papers, the CO grabs them and motions the adjutant away. The CO is shocked by what he hears. He speaks quietly. co Where? But we hit that target a month ago, sir. I thought... The voice on the other end interrupts. co I know we have to put the pressure on, but I almost lost a quarter of my... The 8-2, a scholarly, bespectacled young man, comes in from the balcony and waits to get the CO's attention. Frustrated, exasperated, the CO listens to the voice on the other end. co Yes, sir. Yes, sir, I'll have my ground crews work all night. I was hoping to give them a little break. We're having a dance tonight in honor of the Group's first anniversary... (interrupted again) Yes, I'll give you an update as soon as I know more. Thank you, sir. Goodbye. He hangs up. He's shaken by the news he's received. 8-2 Sir, eighteen planes. Three still out. He nods, then hurries out the door to the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the balcony, COLONEL BRUCE DERRINGER. Bruce is in his mid-thirties, has all-American good looks and an easy-going charm that he can turn on and off at will. Bruce isn't watching the planes landing. He's looking down at the lawn below. The CO comes out on the balcony with the S-2. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: So that's them. co Those are the enlisted men. You're meeting the officers this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: They must be the ten luckiest sons of bitches in the world. co They're ordinary men, Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM the balcony DOWN TO the control tower lawn where our six boys are just joining the crowd below.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? First, they volunteer for this, then they do 24 missions without a scratch. They don't sound very ordinary to me. 8-2 Two more, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CO looks out at arriving planes through his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You know, people at home are getting pretty discouraged by our losses. They're starting to think daylight bombing is a mistake. co It's the only way we're going to win this war.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You're right, and we've got to get that message across. That's where I come in. The nation's going to fall in love with those boys. The first crew in the Eighth Air Force to complete their tour of duty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: co They haven't done it yet.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: They will. You'll make sure of it. He leans on the balcony and looks down at the crew. We MOVE DOWN TO them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six boys anxiously watch for the last plane.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: One more. It'd be great if everyone came back today. With the dance and everything.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I give them four to one. Any takers?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Show me your money, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Gene, lend me some money.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: What do I look like, Wells Fargo?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: There they are! Danny points out at the horizon. The boys are relieved. They push each other around a little, then turn and start walking across the field towards the barracks. SOUND: ENGINE SPUTTERING. (The following dialogue can be used as the men walk away, if needed.)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: I heard they brought in a swell band for the dance tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Clay, maybe they'll let you sing with them.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: No siree. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: You sing to us in the plane all the time.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you guys ain't got no taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is coming in to land. It has two feathered props and only the left front wheel is down. The wheel touches the runway and the plane immediately tips to the right. It pivots on its single wheel, scraping its belly on the runway. The props on the right side bend back, slowing the PLANE's spin. It starts to come to a halt, but just as it looks like it's safe, it EXPLODES in a sudden fiery blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six boys recoil with shock and disbelief. Danny watches as long as he can, then turns away -- he can't stand it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is also looking at the burning plane with horror. The CO is stony-faced. He shows no surprise and little emotion -- he's seen it too often before. co Come on, Bruce, you wanted to meet the officers of the Southern Belle.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Jesus, what happened? They were almost home. co Almost. The pilot came in on one wheel. He should have belly landed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: thru 10 il

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Are they all... ? co What do you think? Let's go, Bruce. He starts off the balcony. Bruce follows, but looks over his shoulder once more at the burning plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLANE continues to burn. There's another small EXPLOSION inside the plane and this BECOMES the white flash of a photographer's camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DENNIS DEARBORN is sitting stiffly in a chair, the bomb group symbol behind him on the mess wall. Dennis, at twenty-six, is the oldest of the crew. He's a serious young man -- you never catch him smiling or relaxing. His photo has just been taken by a Life Magazine photographer. Bruce is behind the camera, interviewing Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You named the plane after your girl back home, that's a great angle. You don't sound like you're from the South, Captain Dearborn.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I met her when I was in Memphis on business.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I bet she's a living doll, huh, Dennis? Dennis looks up at Bruce -- he doesn't like his tone at all.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: She's a very fine woman, sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flash. Now LUKE SINCLAIR, the co-pilot, is in the chair. Luke is twenty-five and about as handsome as they come. He's relaxed, smiling. He loves the attention.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: A lifeguard. That's a pretty responsible job, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's rough basking in the sun all day, having girls swarm all over you. That's why I joined up. Had to get away from all that. Flash. Now VAL KOZLOWSKI the bombardier, is sitting in the hotseat. Val has Latin good looks and a street fighter's body. He's a pretty intense guy. He squirms, pushes at his hair, tries to loosen his collar, straighten his tie.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Val. What's that short for, Valentine? I bet the women love that. You're the bombardier and I understand you've got four years of medical school under your belt.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, something like that.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Believe me, when your picture comes out in Life Magazine, every man, woman and child in America is going to want you to be their doctor. Val brightens at this. Flash. Now PHIL LOWENTHAL is in the chair. Phil's in his early twenties, with a lot of hair and a lot of teeth. He slumps in the chair, moody and gloomy. He'd like to be anywhere but here.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Phil, look at the camera. Sit up straight. Smile.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What's there to smile about, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You guys have finished 24 missions. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One more and you get to go home. That would sure make me smile.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Well, you're not me, sir. (to the photographer) Please just take the picture. He looks up at the camera, a big cloud over his head. Flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis, Luke, Phil and Val are sitting at a table as Bruce addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You'll go back home in your own plane and fly all over the States, making speeches, getting people to buy more war bonds, work longer hours, turn out more planes. And believe me, you'll be wined, womened and songed from one end of the U.S. to the other. It'll be tough, but we all have to make sacrifices. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sir, you mean we're going to be famous?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Afraid so, Luke. Luke whoops. He pounds on Val and Phil a little. Val pushes him away. Phil is hunched over, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Colonel Derringer...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: We'll follow your orders to the best of our... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) It's not an order, Dennis. We're working together.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, but I don't want the other men finding out about this yet.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Their pictures in Life? Wine, women and song? You've got to tell them! They'll go nuts!

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I don't want them going nuts. Right now I want them thinking about their jobs and that's all.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Come on, we could do our jobs in our sleep! Why can't they know?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Because I said so.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: My father used to say that. Dennis and Luke glare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Dennis, you're the boss. Tell your crew when you think it's right. Gentlemen, thank you for your time. Dennis, Luke, Phil and Val start getting up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big tin-roofed Nissen hut, six beds on each side and a HISSING potbellied STOVE in the center. Two crews bunk in here, our enlisted men and another crew. In the b.g., a NEWS REPORT is heard on the RADIO, then MUSIC begins. There's lots of activity as men get ready for the dance. Jack is involved in a poker game at one end of the room. At the other end, Clay is wrenching off the padlock on a locker at the foot of a stripped bunk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny is loading film scene seesaws between the dead man's things getting ready for the 11. in his box camera. (This whole the ominousness of sorting through and the fun and excitement of dance.)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Clay, shouldn't you let the sergeant go stuff? through Becker's

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: The sergeant'll just send it all to Becker's her getting Danny. widow. We don't want anything embarrassing, The lock comes off, Clay opens the locker and starts sorting through the contents. Eugene is putting on his socks. He sniffs them and gags.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Anyone got any clean socks? Hershey bar. Me, me! Clay tosses it to him.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Virge rips it open and starts eating it. Around Virge's bunk are drawings of a restau- rant. As he munches the candy bar, he studies them.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Anyway, Danny, then I'm going to open a whole bunch of restaurants, exactly like the first one. So you can go to Detroit and get the exact same hamburger you got in Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Virge, nobody wants the same old food everywhere they go.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Sure they do. It's comforting.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Love letters.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Wife or girl friend? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clay opens one and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Read 'em out loud! Get me in the mood for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Girl friend. He tosses the letters to Virge, who puts them in the stove.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Does Becker have any clean socks in there? Eugene goes over to the locker, searches for socks. Clay puts the next few items in a pile on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Air medal, photos, pocket knife. Dirty book!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'll take it. Clay tosses the paperback to Danny: God's Little Acre, with a lurid cover. Danny flips through it. In the middle is stuck: a four-leaf clover wrapped in cellophane.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Look. Becker forgot his good luck charm.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Poor slob.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: He should of worn it around his neck. Then you never lose it. He kisses his St. Anthony medal.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Rubbers.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Dibs! Clay tosses them to him. Then puts some other things on the bed in the widow's pile: money, a compass, a diary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: We know Virge the Virgin won't need them. Virge, you gotta promise if you ever lose your cherry, you'll tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: I'll send it to you. C.O.D. Eugene starts searching his bunk area. Jack comes run- ning up and takes some money from the pile on Becker's bunk.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Becker owed me ten.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jack, don't take his money!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He owed it to me! Hey, what do you guys know about Germany?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Pretty women.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good beer.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: The hamburger's named after a town there.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, a little bird told me that's where they're sending us tomorrow. The men react with disbelief and shock.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: We ain't going to Krautville. Our plane's broke.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: No, it's fixed.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Christ, let's go break it! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Anybody want the rest of this stuff? Virge, Danny, Rascal, Jack and Eugene start towards the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: Clay dispenses the rest of Becker's possessions with the other men standing around the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Deck of cards. Razor blades. Lucky Strikes. Shoelaces. Pack of Doublemint... Rascal takes the cards, Jack the razor blades, Danny the cigarettes, Eugene the shoelaces, Virge the gum. We start to hear BIG BAND MUSIC and we're in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been turned into a dance hall for the night: streamers, a mirror ball, a bar and a big band. The dance is in full swing. Jack is dancing with a shy skinny girl and Eugene is dancing with a boisterous big girl. It looks like they're with the wrong partners. Eugene swings under the big girl's arm, kicks Jack in the butt when his back is turned, then quickly swings back into the big girl's arms. Jack looks around, but has no idea where the kick came from.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: He snaps a picture of them.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: talking to a pretty English girl, FAITH. He's really milking this for all the sympathy he can get.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Now they're saying maybe we're going to Germany tomorrow... my short, young life could just be snuffed out in an instant. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I volunteered 'cause I thought it would be fun. I never thought I could get... He chokes up. Faith looks away.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: standing across the room, alone, shy and very cute.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: is so wrapped up in his pitch he doesn't realize Faith's attention has wandered.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Oh, Faith, when I think I might never see the stars again or hear good music or talk to a beautiful girl like you... (wipes away a tear) Sorry. You need a drink. I'll be right back. He takes her glass and hurries over to the bar. It's packed. Val is there, checking out the girls on the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: She's crazy about me. She's going to jump on me any second. He burrows his way into the crowd. Phil comes up with a brimming glass of whiskey. He's already a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Phil, come on, you've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How come they brought Life Magazine over and everything? Are they trying to jinx us?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Just forget it. Let's find us a couple girls. Val looks out at the dance floor. Phil comes up to him, close. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Val, tell me the truth. The truth. Are you scared?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I'm Val. Come on. He takes Phil's glass from him, sets it down on a nearby table and pulls Phil toward the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: is with Virge. He's excitedly talking about his restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: You've never had a hamburger? That's unbelievable. You don't know what you're missing.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: They sound wonderful. It's been so long since I've had any meat. Virge takes Faith's hand and demonstrates his technique. He has no idea he's turning her on.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: See, I work the meat very slowly, very tenderly. That's the secret. Rub in a little Worcestershire, a little garlic, a little thyme. Then ease it into a patty... gentle, gentle, so I don't bruise the meat.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Virge, you're making me so hungry!

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: comes out of the mob at the bar with Faith's drink. He looks around to where Faith was waiting, but she's not there. She's nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE AND LUKE
dialogues.text: sitting at a table with a couple of girls. They've obviously become the best of buddies.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Ever done any public speaking, Luke?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: A little acting. Amateur stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I bet you were good. We're going to have to excite people on this bond tour. Inspire them. Dennis is a fine man, but he doesn't have your enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I'm a qualified pilot, same as him. They just didn't have a plane for me. So, he's the big shot pilot and I'm sitting in the dummy seat.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You're no dummy, Luke. We both know that. Bruce puts a hand on Luke's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: standing with the ROOKIE LIEUTENANT, a fresh-faced, very naive young man. Dennis is trying to describe the excitement and responsibility of being a pilot, but he's inarticulate. The Rookie Lieutenant has no idea what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Just wait till you go up for the first time. You've got four thousand pounds of bombs in your belly, nine other men are depending on you to make the right decision. It's... (beat) Everything you ever did before seems so... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) You're really alive up there, that's what I'm getting at. You'll see what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Well, uh, thanks a lot, Captain. I've got to get a refill. The Rookie Lieutenant hurries off, anxious to get away from Dennis. Dennis looks across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Luke at the table with with the girls, having a great time, laughing, chatting.

dialogues.speaker: ON DENNIS
dialogues.text: Feeling alienated, alone, he turns and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark, foggy. Dennis walks across the field toward another hangar, a beer in his hand. The BAND can be heard in the DISTANCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is brightly, starkly lit with floodlights. There are planes and parts of planes crowded in here with ground crews crawling over them. It is an epic sight, showing the huge scale of the air war and the number of men required to sustain it. In the f.g. is a plane, "Is You Is Or Is You Ain't My Baby?" The pilot's window is shattered, a front tire is flat, a chunk has been taken out of the tail, the ball turret is broken in half and what remains is covered in dried blood. A mechanic is hosing it out. LES ENRIGHT, a stocky man in his mid- thirties, wearing grease-stained coveralls, is helping carry a new ball turret over to the plane. Dennis goes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Les, what are you doing here? You're my ground crew chief. You're supposed to be working on my plane.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm just helping out... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: You should be giving the supercharger on Number One your...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Supercharger's fixed.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Okay, but how about the cowl flaps on...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Number three's fixed. It's all fixed. You don't have to tell me my job, Captain. Watch your feet. A dark red pool is gathering right at Dennis feet. Dennis looks down, sees it and steps away.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: The Belle's in mint condition. If you don't believe me, go look at her. She's out on the apron, Sir. Les turns back to work. A moment. Dennis knows he jumped on Les a little too fast, but he also doesn't want to apologize. He turns and goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see only the vague outline of the Belle through the fog as Dennis approaches. He stops in front of the nose and speaks to the plane.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going to miss you, girl. We've been together a long time and you've never let me down. I can't say that about many people. You know how to take care of your man and that's just about the best thing a fellow can say about a girl, I guess. Maybe we'll be going back to the States together, but it won't be the same, will it? It won't have the same... He searches for the word, can't find it, then starts to take a drink. But he decides he's had enough and pours the rest of the beer on the ground. He turns and walks back across the field to the dance. Then a head pops up and looks out through the nose of the plane: Virge.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: I wish you'd talk to me like that, Virge.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking forward, we see Virge and Faith in silhouette. They've put something down on the floor of the plane as a makeshift bed, perhaps some parachutes.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: You know what the captain would do if he caught us in here? He'd murder me. Come on, Faith, let's get this over with and get back to the dance. They try to get it going again.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Wait, there's something... Hold on. There! Sorry. Faith pulls something out from under her. Virge grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: My wrench! I've been looking for that all over! Where'd you find it?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Under my bum.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. Boy, I thought someone stole it.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Virge, forget the bloody wrench. She grabs him and kisses him. A CLUNK as he drops the WRENCH and kisses her back.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: You've never done this before, have you?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Why, am I doing something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No. You're doing everything just right. He embraces her and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virge and Faith are near the hangar door. He kisses her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: el.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: That was...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it really was. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want this to get around.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Around?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I know what you Yanks are like, always bragging about your women.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Oh, no! Gosh, I wouldn't... Not if you...

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Thanks. Well... She smiles, touches his face.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll pop â€˜round for a hamburger some day. She turns and goes back into the hangar. Virge starts to go with her. She puts a hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: I'll go in first, if that's...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Oh, sure! Go right ahead. She smiles at him, then goes into the hangar. Virge watches her go in. Then, when he's alone, he takes a deep breath, then howls at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is in full swing. Everyone's having a great time.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: co sitting at a table with his men -- but he's remote, lost in his own thoughts. He knows that some of these men will die over Germany tomorrow and the thought makes it impossible for him to join in the fun.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET TABLE
dialogues.text: Food and coffee are set out. Danny, Jack and Eugene are eating while Rascal holds court with a group of fresh- faced rookies. One of them, the ROOKIE, is their spokesman.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: That yours, that brand new plane out there?

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Mother and Country.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: (patronizingly) Mother and Country. He looks at Jack and Eugene and they sigh.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL, JACK
dialogues.text: Ahhh...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ain't that sweet?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Brings a tear to the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: We had our first practice today.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) We need a couple more. If you guys have any advice for us or anything...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Get a gun, shoot your big toe off and go home. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: That's good advice.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Hallelujah, brother.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Come on, guys. Rascal puts an arm around the Rookie and looks down at the Rookie's shiny shoes.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Are those size eight? How about leaving a little will saying when you get your ass shot off on your first mission, those nice shiny new pumps come to me? The Rookie turns pale and breaks away from Rascal. He runs out the door. Rascal chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Rascal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny comes into the latrine. The fresh-faced Rookie is bent over one of the toilet bowls, having just thrown up. He's pale and woozy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Nerves, I guess. Danny fills a tin cup with water and takes it over to him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: They were just fooling around. Don't worry about it. Everyone gets kidding like that at first.

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: I give anything to be in your shoes. One more and you get to go home. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I could stay. Sounds crazy, but I'm used to it here. And the guys are like brothers to me. I never had brothers. Four sisters. (laughs) When we go back home, I don't know when we're going to get together again. We come from all over. I guess that's why I keep taking their pictures. He looks down at his camera, winds it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's the way you'll be with your crew. Here. Danny reaches into his breast pocket and takes out the four-leaf clover and holds it out to the Rookie. He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and the Rookie join Jack, Eugene, Rascal and Clay just as the band is ending a number.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Clay, now's your chance! Get up there and sing!

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I'm not gonna make a fool of myself in front of all these folks.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Come on, you're a great singer. There's a fanfare from the band. Bruce gets up onstage and speaks into the microphone. He's enthusiastic and is blind to the fact that what he's saying is bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen... There's ten very special men here tonight. I'm sure you know who I mean. The crew of the Memphis Belle. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: el 25.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're just about to become the first crew in the Eighth Air Force to fly their twenty-fifth and final mission. Let's hear it for them! Hip hip...!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, CLAY, JACK AND EUGENE
dialogues.text: unhappily watching Bruce. The Rookie starts to complete the cheer.

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: Hooray... Danny grabs his arm to stop him. A couple of other rookies have started to cheer, but they also quickly shut up. A grim silence falls over the hangar. Bruce is embarrassed and doesn't know what to do. Danny looks at Clay -- a look saying "Do something." Clay quickly goes through the crowd and steps up onstage and takes the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: This buddy of mine keeps begging me to sing and I guess I ain't gonna get out of it this time. Clay says a few words to the band leader, then turns back to the microphone. In the meantime, Bruce quietly leaves the stage. The band begins.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: (sings) 'Oh, Danny Boy, The pipes, the pipes are calling...'

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: He blushes and tries to escape. Jack and Eugene grab Danny and force him to stay. The Rookie smiles, enjoying this -- this is what Danny was talking about.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: 'From glen to glen, And down the mountain side...' Then suddenly, without warning, Clay and the band go into an up-tempo, jazzy version of the song. Clay's good -- he's a natural. Everyone starts to dance. In no time at all the hangar is swinging again.  22 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is alone out in the middle of the field. The SONG can be heard IN the DISTANCE. Phil holds a nearly full bottle of Scotch. He looks up at the moon, diffused through a layer of fog. He shouts.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don't want to die, I don't want to die, I don't want to die... His call fades away. He takes a long drink from the bottle. He stumles a little, then wanders off, disap- pearing into the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horizon is just starting to fill with light. The fog is gone and the clouds are breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: MEMPHIS BELLE
dialogues.text: The Plexiglas of the nose, top turret and ball turret reflect the bright sunrise. It's a B-17F, olive green with a grey belly. On the nose, there's a painting of a leggy woman in a bathing suit. Also, twenty-four yellow bomb emblems and eight swastikas. The big forward landing gear gives it a wide stance and the nose points into the air, as if eager to take off. The plane is huge, so huge it doesn't look like it could ever get off the ground. It's a dramatic sight, the sun coming up yellow and hot behind this 30 tons of machine. Men are feverishly working on the plane, getting it ready, load- ing the bombs, checking every detail again and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barracks is dark. Danny is in bed, asleep. Suddenly, a flashlight is flipped on, right in his face.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Daly, rise 'n' shine. Mission oh-eight-hundred. Danny squints up at the pie-faced SERGEANT.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay. The Sergeant shines the flashlight in Rascal's face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Moore. Up and at 'em.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: I just went to sleep! He pulls the covers over his head. Other men are starting to wake up, groaning, hacking.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Alla yous guys, get crackin'! Clay sits up and starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: (sings) 'Oh, how I hate to get up in the morning...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is identical to the enlisted men's Nissen hut, but less crowded with six bunks, rather than twelve. The Sergeant shines the light in Dennis's face.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Captain Dearborn, mission today. Breakfast oh-six-hundred, briefing, oh-six-forty-five. Dennis wakes and looks at his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Sinclair. In the bed next to Dennis's Luke is already starting to awake. His dog is sleeping beside him on the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I'm up. The Sergeant moves his flashlight across the aisle to Phil's bed. It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Where's Lieutenant Lowenthal?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Phil? I don't know. Val, where's Phil? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Sergeant moves the flashlight to Val. Val quickly improvises.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: He's in the can. Couldn't sleep. Nerves.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: I don't blame him. Give â€˜em hell today.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Will do. Dennis starts to get up. Behind his back, Val and Luke exchange a glance. They have no idea where Phil is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Val, dressed, comes out of the barracks. It rained during the night and the ground is muddy. Men are hurrying for the latrine and mess hall. Jeeps go by, splashing mud. Val starts jogging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Val jogs around the perimeter track. Planes are on their individual hardstands, with ground crews crawling over them. Gas trucks and bomb carts come and go. Ordinance crews are loading fat olive drab bombs into the bellies of the planes. Armament crews are putting boxes of ammunition in the planes and checking the gun turrets. Val looks around for Phil, but there's no sign of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that remains of the dance is some beer bottles, playing cards and cigarettes on the ground. The hangar door is open and we can see that it has turned back into a repair shop. A damaged B-17 is being cannibalized for its parts. Val looks around, stumped. Suddenly, a voice cries out.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Bogey, six o'clock low! Phil tackles Val from behind and knocks him to the ground. Val scrambles out from under Phil and gets to his feet. Phil sits in the mud, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: You're drunk! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (deliberately slurring) I rethent that inthinuation! He takes a drink from his bottle of Scotch -- it's almost empty.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? We've got a mission! Val grabs the bottle away from Phil, then tries to pull Phil up. He's wasted.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I know, that's why. I'm gonna get it today, Val. My luck's up, my number's run out. I mean... (giggles) I'm gonna die and I want to give you something to remember me by. He takes off his watch.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I don't want that piece of crap. You've got to get hold of yourself. Everybody's counting on you... Arm around Phil, he starts leading him back to the barracks.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You want my cufflinks? They've got my initials.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Phil, you're going to let everyone down...

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How about my whole set of New York Yankee baseball cards? Nah, then you'll just remember the Yankees and forget about me. Phil continues to ramble as Val leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I know, my fountain pen! You could use it to fill out prescriptions and stuff. Or you name it, Val. Anything you want. My dog tags? You want my dog tags or my Boy Scout knife?  28 29 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are men in here, shaving, sleepily getting ready for the mission. Val and Luke watch Phil weave towards a stall. He misses the door and bumps into the doorjamb.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: That's our navigator. Phil disappears into the stall.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: We better tell Dennis he's sick and get someone else.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We can't! <A new man's bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: What's a drunk navigator, good luck?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So, you're the doctor. Sober him up.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: He's going to endanger every man in that...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Come on, he's not so bad. He's just a little high. Sound of a TRICKLE from the stall. Val glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: I timed that. Forty-five seconds to find his own dick. Val and Luke look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Val bends Phil over the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Stick your finger down your throat. Phil shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Do it or I'll do it for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Phil tries to get away. Val shoves him up against the wall, pries open his mouth and sticks his own finger down Phil's throat. Phil gags and vomits, right on Val's shirt and tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enlisted men are getting dressed and shaving. Danny takes a picture of the hut, and the men groan. The men are tense, nervous, but they cover their anxiety with jokes and foolishness.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can see it. I get back home, I'm making love to my wife, the door breaks open and it's Danny, taking a fucking picture! Danny laughs. He turns his camera on Eugene, who's searching his bunk, in a state of near panic.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Anybody seen my St. Anthony medal?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Isn't he the patron saint of missing things?

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can't find him! Danny takes the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Val is shaving Phil, who's shivering, a wreck. Val's shirt is wet -- he has washed off the vomit. Luke comes in.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Coast's clear. Dennis went for chow. Phil pulls a Boy Scout knife out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Luke, I want you to have my penknife. It's real nice.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Keep it. If Dennis sees you like this, you'll need it to cut your throat with. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Luke rips open a little packet and empties it in Phil's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Sen-sen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny takes the bottle of champagne from his locker. Rascal snatches it away from him.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: You're not thinking of sneaking this on the plane, are you? Danny, I am shocked. And Virge goes out for the pass! He tosses it across the room to Virge.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Don't!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey, wiseguys, cut the crap!

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: I found it! He finds his St. Anthony medal under his bed. He slips the chain over his head, kisses the medallion and falls to his knees to say a little prayer. Rascal and Virge continue to play keepaway from Danny, annoying the other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is dressed and Val is tying his shoes. Phil hiccups.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Stop it! Phil hiccups again. Just then, a quick KNOCK, the door opens and Dennis comes in.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: There you are, Phil. I just want to remind you both to keep quiet about you know what.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: What? Oh, sure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Phil nods.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Okay. See you at briefing. He goes out, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: (to Phil) You did good. Phil lets out a loud hiccup he'd been saving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's crowded and smoky. The enlisted men are jammed together on one side of the hall. The officers have more space on their side. Val and Phil are going down the line. A tough Army COOK is serving eggs, bacon and pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: We're counting on you today, sirs. Kick Hitler's butt.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Give him extra. He's real hungry. The Cook heaps some more eggs on the plate. Phil watches, nauseated.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, VIRGE, EUGENE, JACK, RASCAL AND DANNY
dialogues.text: are crowded at a table, all smoking and drinking coffee. Jack is the only one eating.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: These powdered eggs would gag a buzzard. He takes Virge's plate and scrapes the eggs onto his plate and eats those, too. Luke and Dennis come over.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: How are we doing this morning, men? Luke puts a hammerhold on Rascal's neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Stop it! You won't have a chance to do that after today, Luke, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be so sure. Right, Dennis? Suddenly, across the room, a CRASH and CLATTER. Everyone looks. Val is scurrying to retrieve a box of silverware Phil knocked over. Dennis watches. Luke watches Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I guess we've all got the jitters this morning. See you after briefing. Dennis walks off. Luke breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up front, a small stage. On stage, a board covered by a curtain. On the left side, a spool of red yarn, the yarn leading behind the curtain. The room is crowded, noisy and smoky. Val escorts Phil to a seat in the back. He's nearly comatose. Luke comes up to them, holding his dog, a brown and white speckled mutt.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: How the hell's he going to get through the navigator's briefing afterwards?

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: On a wing and a fucking prayer. Val and Phil sit. Luke leaves them to take his seat down front with Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND ROOKIE
dialogues.text: sitting across the aisle with the other radio operators.

dialogues.speaker: ROOKIE
dialogues.text: I thought we'd have a little more practice before we went up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You'll do fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny takes out a couple of pencils and gives the Rookie one, then turns to a fresh sheet in his notebook. Suddenly, a sharp voice calls out.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tenn-hut! Everyone rises to attention. The CO steps up on stage. co At ease, gentlemen. Murmuring and shuffling as everyone sits. co I hope you all had a good time last night. But now it's back to business. The target for today is... The S-2 pulls back the curtain to reveal a map of Northern Europe. The red yarn extends from East Anglia all the way across the North Sea, then turns sharply and penetrates into Germany. co Bremen. The room erupts into disbelief, gasps, groans, nervous laughter. First we see Dennis and Luke, then Phil and Val, then Danny and the Rookie, all looking at the map in shock. They weren't expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CO hurries out of the briefing room. Bruce is waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (angrily) Are you crazy? Bremen's one of the most heavily-defended cities in Germany! They'll get blown out of the sky. You've got to pull the Memphis Belle from this mission. co No.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I need those men. This whole public relations junket depends... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: co (interrupting) I have orders to put every plane in the sky that I can.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Craig, if we present a united front, the two of us, we can get the Belle pulled. You talk to H.Q. I'll talk to Washington. co I promised General Eaker 24 planes today. I lost one yesterday. The Memphis Belle has to go.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You don't really care if those men live or die, do you? They're just another plane to you. Just so you can reach your quota. co Colonel, I'm in command here and I've made my decision!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Your decision is inhuman and irresponsible, and I'm going to make sure everybody knows about it, starting with General Eaker. Bruce turns and jogs across the base, dodging a Jeep as he goes. The CO watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are off. A large blown-up photograph is projected on the screen: an aerial view of a railyard, a river snaking through, some trees and houses. The 8-2 taps a large, square building in the center of the photo with his pointer. He taps it three times. 8-2 This is our target right here. It's a square building, the only square one in the area, so you can't miss it. Note these railroad tracks on the east and this long, rectangular building on the north. That's a hospital. These are houses here. This is a school and a playground. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ON VAL
dialogues.text: He's watching very carefully. This is his department. He stares at the picture, trying to memorize every detail. Beside him, Phil is fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with men in various stages of dress, Rascal, Clay, Jack, Eugene and Virge among them. They wear long underwear next to their skin, then bright blue heated suits over that. Pants and blouse over that. Then a leather flight jacket with a long extension cord sticking out. The blue bunny suits plug into the waist of the flight jacket. Thick, fleece-lined boots and gloves are next, a wool scarf, a helmet, and, finally, a Mae West, a deflated yellow life jacket. Rascal is fully-dressed and looks a little stocky with all these clothes on. Clay is just pulling on his long underwear and he sings as he does it.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: (sings) 'I'm putting on my top hat, Tying up my white tie, Brushing off my tails...'

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: There he goes, the human jukebox. Clay buttons up the front of his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: (sings) 'I'm duding up my shirt front, Putting in the shirt studs, Polishing my nails...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CO is now standing on the stage. The room is silent. He speaks with quiet force and feeling, but careful not to let his anxiety and anguish show. co Today they've given us a chance to really make a difference in this war. Let's do this job the best we can and leave the rest in the hands of God. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: co (CONT'D) With luck it'll all be over soon and we can go back home to our families. My thoughts will be with you and I won't rest until you're back. Each and every one of you. Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is yelling into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I've talked to six different people and been cut off twice! I want General Eaker on this phone now or I want your name, Corporal. I'll hold, but you better not cut me... A second, then he jiggles the cradle. He's been cut off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The navigator's briefing is in progress. In the back, two lines: one for radio operators (Danny and the Rookie in this one) and one for bombardiers. Val is lined up to receive his flimsies, Luke with him. They're both watch- ing Phil. The GROUP NAVIGATOR drones on in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP NAVIGATOR
dialogues.text: You'll have nil to 3/10 low clouds at takeoff with visibility one to two miles. You'll assemble over the field at 3,000 feet...

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: So far, so good.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHIL
dialogues.text: He's awake and paying attention. Then we see why. He's jabbing the sharp point of his compass into his forearm. It's spotted with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay, Eugene, Jack, Virge and Rascal are piled into the back of a Jeep parked on the edge of the perimeter track. They stare at Danny in shock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Bremen! We're dead men! We're dead!

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Rascal!

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: You shut up, Virgin!

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Cut it out. Clay, what're the odds today?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: (calmly, objectively) Well, they'll overload us with bombs, so it's about thirty to one we'll crash and blow up on takeoff. Then, they're going to throw every fighter they've got at us, so, five to one against us even getting to Bremen. Then, you've got your flak batteries...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Skip the gory details.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Basically, we're fucked. Then Dennis walks up, Luke, Val and Phil behind him. As soon as the enlisted men see Dennis they smile and try to look innocent and happy to be going to Bremen. Without a word, Dennis gets in the front seat of the Jeep and the enlisted men make room for the other officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all in the Jeep, some seated, others hanging on to the back or sides. They're being driven across the field. Luke's DOG runs along with the Jeep, BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jeep halts at the plane. The crew gets up and starts for the hatches. The ground crew is doing a final check, crawling all over the plane. Les is supervising.  45 46 47 48 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of dials and switches on the instrument panel. More gadgets on the left and right walls. Between the pilot and co-pilot seats is a pedestal with the ignition switches, engine controls and throttles. Below that, another box with switches and wheels controlling the trim tabs, elevators and rudders. Luke sits in the co-pilot seat. He plugs in his intercom and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Soon as you're ready, call in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front of the nose is Plexiglas. There are two guns on the sides, right and left. Under the right gun, an intricate panel of bombing instruments. There are more instruments, dials, gauges and buttons -- including the bomb release switch -- on the left. Val takes the canvas cover off a complicated device in the very tip of the nose: the Norden bombsight. He wipes it carefully with a cloth.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Bombardier checking in. Phil is behind him at a little desk that juts out of the left wall. Above and behind his desk is more equipment: hoses, gauges, compasses. In the ceiling, a small Plexiglas dome. Phil very neatly arranges his pencils, compasses, rulers, maps, flimsies, log book -- everything in its place.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Navigator checking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Directly behind the cockpit is a small platform where Virge stands. He's checking his twin .50 caliber machine guns in the top turret. They stick out of a small Plexiglas bubble in the roof. The TURRET is hydraulically-operated with hand controls; it WHINES and CLANKS as it rotates. Directly behind the top turret is the bomb bay.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Top turret checking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the bomb bay is Danny's radio room. He has a desk against the left forward bulkhead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His radio receivers, transmitters and Morse code key are on the desk. Additional equipment is on little shelves bolted to the right bulkheads, fore and aft. A .50 caliber machine gun points out of a small window in the ceiling -- Danny's gun. Danny has his headphones on, his codebooks open, and is making notations in his log book. His box camera is also on the desk. On his wrist he wears a big red rubber band.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Radio operator checking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An area that contains the top of the ball turret. Rascal is checking his ammunition boxes.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Ball turret checking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two large open windows on either side of the plane. The plane has tapered and is much narrower towards the back. Jack and Eugene are on their respective sides of the fuselage, checking their guns and ammo. When in action, Jack and Eugene are hip to hip, with no room to spare.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Right waist gunner checking in.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Left waist checking in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tail gun position is very cramped. There's only room for one man and he has to kneel in front of his twin -50s. His head sticks up into a rectangular box with small windows in it, providing maximum view and minimum protection. Clay adjusts the rope of ammunition which leads from the ammo box to the guns. Clay's lucky horseshoe hangs on the left.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Tail gunner checking in. In this section we should have the sense that each crew member knows his job inside out and gives it his fullest attention. No horsing around now.  52 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis and Luke are in their seats. Dennis checks off items on a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Auto pilot.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: off.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: De-icers, anti-icers.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: off.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Generators.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: off.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Good. Crew, assume positions for takeoff. Virge jumps down from the top turret and crouches behind the control box. Then he taps Dennis on the shoulder and points. Racing towards them across the tarmac is a Jeep. Dennis opens his side window. The Jeep slows and a LIEUTENANT yells up to Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Captain, there's a delay. We've got a 9/10ths cloud cover over the target. But there's a strong wind and we're hoping it'll blow over. Stand by your plane until further notice.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: They don't tell me doodly, sir. The Jeep pulls away. Luke pounds the control column in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Damnit! They always do this! Dennis speaks over the interphone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Men, we're delayed. There's cloud over the target. They're asking us to stand by until further notice. Danny, tell the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny turns around and speaks to Jack, Eugene, Rascal and Clay.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The target's clouded up. We're delayed. The other guys look at each other, disappointed and relieved at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Snafu.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Situation normal...

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL, JACK, EUGENE, CLAY
dialogues.text: All fucked up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke is unplugging his interphone cord and taking off his headset. Virge is still crouched behind the control box. Dennis speaks over the interphone.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, we're stood down for a while. Let's take the extra time to double-double check everything. Let's make this mission our best one yet. Virge steps up into the top turret. Luke starts getting up from his seat.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Okay, Luke, let's do the pre- flight check again. Fuel Transfer Valves. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Did you hear? There's a complete cloud cover over Bremen. We're not going anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Fuel Transfer Valves.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Off! They were off before! They're still off!

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Intercoolers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil drops out of the forward hatch and walks under the belly of the plane. He hoists himself up onto the left wing, lies down, puts a parachute under his head as a pillow and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the airfield, a hedgerow and beyond it, a farmhouse, crops, some sheep grazing. Clay calls across to a ruddy FARMER, who's trying to repair an ancient horse-pulled combine baler.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Busted?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: It's no use, Yank. This thing's old as the hills and there's not a spare part to be found these days.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I've got one just like it at home. Let me take a look. Clay goes to a gap in the hedgerow where part of a roll of barbed wire is stuck. Clay pulls it out and steps through the hedge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is on the phone as the CO comes in. Bruce is really wound up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Well, wake him up at home! (covers phone, then to CO) Washington. co Bruce, I won't tolerate this. If I have to, I'll have you arrested and locked up until takeoff.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Craig, there won't be any more takeoffs if we can't convince people back home daylight bombing makes sense. With the Belle I can say, look, they made it, they survived 25... co Bruce, if the weather changes, they're going. The door opens and the S-2 enters. 8-2 Sir, it looks like that cloud cover is breaking up. H.Q. will make a decision in the next ten, fifteen minutes. co Thank you, Corporal. The S-2 leaves. The CO and Bruce look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baler alongside

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: A lot can happen in fifteen minutes. (in phone) Yes, I'm still here! Great! You bet I'll hold. is fixed and Clay is riding it. Luke walks and throws a stick to his dog, who chases it. Luke is frustrated and impatient with the stand-down. This whole section has anxiety and tension to it. Are they going up or not? Why is it always "hurry up and wait?" (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: All you do is call up on the intercom and say you're having trouble in the tail. I'11 come back and you let me have the gun for five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: It's against regulations.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Screw regulations. This is my last chance. How am I going to get girls when I go back home if I haven't killed a single Nazi?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: If they found out, they'd put my hot dog in a bun and chow down.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Nobody's going to find out. It's just between us. I'll do anything you say. Name your price. The dog charges back with the stick and jumps into Luke's arms.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Give me your dog. Luke looks at Clay, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virge and Rascal by the ball turret. Virge is putting his tools back in the toolbox. Frustrated by the hiatus, Virge and Rascal are on each other's nerves more than ever.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: You're flight engineer...

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: I'm flight engineer when we're in flight. Les is ground crew chief and he checked it out and it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: I know, but look at it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: I just did! Rascal, how many times...? You're just nervous

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: I'm not just nervous! It jammed last mission! I'm the one who has to sit in this rat trap!

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: I checked it, top to bottom. It's okay. Take it easy, Rascal. Virge picks up his toolbox and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Gee, thanks, Virgin.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: The name is Virgil.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Not to me.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: You know, Rascal, I could tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: What? Tell me, Virgin. Virge hesitates. He'd love to tell Rascal and get him off his back. But he can't -- he promised Faith.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Nothing. He walks away. Rascal continues worrying over the turret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has clouded up a bit. It's quiet. The crew is gathered on the left side of the plane. Phil is still asleep on the wing. Dennis is looking over his flimsies and Clay is whittling a model of the Belle out of soft, white wood. The other guys are nervous, anxious, jumpy. Val is compulsively doing sit-ups, one after another. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rascal can't keep still, he's drumming his fingers on his knees, bouncing his legs up and down, etc. Eugene is running his St. Anthony medal up and down its chain while Jack is doing sleight of hand, pulling sticks of gum out of Eugene's nose and ears. Luke is fooling around with his dog. Danny is writing in a composition book. Virge is oiling and cleaning the tools in his toolbox. One slips out of his hand and drops into the box with a clang. Eugene, Jack and Rascal jump.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Virge, do you have to?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Sorry, I just...

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Stop it! Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Seven to one we're not going.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Let's just go. Just get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'd rather get it over by going to a nice little French target.

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, so if we have to bail out, we could hide in some little French girl's hayloft.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Is that all you think about, Rascal?

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: Gotta make up for you, Virgin. Take up the slack. Virge shoves him. Rascal goes for him. Eugene grabs Rascal, Clay grabs Virge.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Okay, men, calm down. Getting excited isn't going to do any good. Relax. Be more like Phil. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Luke and Val exchange a look -- if Dennis only knew. Then Jack grabs Danny's composition book.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What're you writing, Danny Boy? Poetry! We have a poet on the plane!

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Give it back, King Kong. Eugene snatches the book from Jack, tosses it to Clay, who tosses it to Virge, who gives it back to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Read us something you wrote, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: RASCAL
dialogues.text: I wanna hear some poetry!

dialogues.speaker: VIRGE
dialogues.text: Come on, come on.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nothing's finished.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Don't be shy, Danny. Jack takes out his harmonica and starts playing a little of "Danny Boy." Danny blushes. They all look at him, waiting. Reluctantly, Danny opens his book.

dialogues.speaker: NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: Everything is crossed out. He turns a page or two. Same thing, everything is crossed out.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: Everyone is watching him. He looks down at the book and pretends to read. He starts nervously.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: 'I know that I shall meet my fate Somewhere among the clouds above; Those that I fight I do not hate, Those that I guard I do not love...! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hesitates. They're listening. It's very quiet, just the harmonica. Danny recites from memory.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: 'Nor law, nor duty bade me fight,' 'Nor public men, nor cheering crowds, A lonely impulse of delight Drove to this tumult in the clouds; I balanced all, brought all to mind, The years to come seemed waste of breath, A waste of breath the years behind, In balance with this life, this death.! Long, long silence. The words have expressed the feel- ings of each of these men, the attraction to the fight and the fear of it; the threat of death and the excite- ment of its closeness. We FOCUS ON Dennis -- he's particularly struck by the poem. This is a moment suspended in time -- then it's abruptly broken when the JEEP races up, SKIDS to a halt and the Lieutenant yells to Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Captain, you're going up! Takeoff's in five minutes! The Jeep speeds away. The men quickly grab their clothes and equipment and start towards the hatches. Val shakes Phil awake and helps him down from the wing. Clay pulls on his jacket and speaks to Luke.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Okay, Lieutenant, it's a deal.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I'm not giving you my dog.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I don't want that flea-bitten, mangy pooch anyway. Clay jogs off to the waist hatch. Luke puts the dog down, pats him, then also heads for the waist hatch. The dog watches him go, then charges across the field toward the control tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke climbs into his seat and plugs himself in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Let's do the preflight check again for good luck. Dennis picks up his clipboard and pencil, then hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Luke, if we could decide right now, do we go or do we stay... what would you choose?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Go! I can't wait! He grabs the clipboard and pencil from Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Fuel transfer valves. Open. He starts going through the checklist for the third time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CO nods to the 8-2, who points a flare GUN in the air and FIRES. A green flare shoots up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis flips a switch on the pilot's control panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prop on ENGINE one begins turning, then COUGHS and BELCHES a white cloud of smoke. The prop whirls into invisibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is sitting at his desk, tuning his radio, making notes and eating a candy bar. Rascal and Clay are sit- ting on the floor against the left aft bulkhead. Rascal compulsively shuffles a deck of cards. Clay is whittling again. Jack and Eugene sit against the right aft bulk- head. Jack practices his magic on Eugene, making a coin disappear, then pulling it out of Eugene's nose. Eugene is praying and tries to brush Jack away. But Jack per- sists, pulling a piece of gum out of Eugene's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENGINE TWO COUGHS and STARTS UP.  73 74 75 76 77 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil's desk is vibrating so much it's hard to keep things in order. His maps slide onto the floor. He picks them up, then his compass falls off, then his ruler. He picks them up and puts them in place, then his maps slide to the floor again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENGINE THREE WHIRLS into action. Then ENGINE FOUR STARTS UP. ENGINES are POUNDING, rattling the ground all over the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CO is on the control tower balcony, watching the scene through binoculars. Bruce comes out of the control room, steamed that his efforts to stop the Belle have failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les signals to the ground crew to pull the chocks out from under the front wheels. As two members of the ground crew do it, we see them up CLOSE, then we PULL BACK WITH them and the plane is revealed with all four ENGINES POUNDING, props whirling with tremendous speed and power. The plane begins to move forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROAR of ENGINES is deafening as twenty-two planes start moving off the hardstands onto the runways, getting into position for takeoff. There's no turning back now. The sheer mechanical and human effort to get to this point is monumental, exciting. Once they're in line, we see them FROM ABOVE -- plane after plane after plane after plane, ENGINES ROARING, the air wrinkled with their fumes, waiting to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke looks down at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH
dialogues.text: It is exactly 9:00.  80 81 82 thru 92 93 94 95 thru 103 104 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The S-2 FIRES a second flare: this one splits into two green prongs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lead plane, Windy City, opens its throttles and hurtles down the runway and soars into the sky, surpris- ingly graceful. Then another plane, Mama's Boys, charges down the runway and takes off. Then a third plane, C CUP, ROARS down the runway and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Memphis Belle starts down the runway. We TRACK WITH it, keeping pace as it picks up speed, steadily, smoothly The wheels start to lift off the runway. The plane, which has seemed too heavy to ever get off the ground, takes to the air gracefully, naturally. It soars. Finally, we can't keep up with it and we watch as it flies off into the horizon, its ROAR DIMINISHING and leaving us with silence and an empty feeling. We can't help them now. They're on their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les and the ground crew watch the plane until it's gone. They feel helpless. Les, exhausted from working twenty- four hours to get to this moment, turns away and picks up his bicycle from the ground. He starts to ride back to the barracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're inside now. We're rising fast and flying towards a huge, dense cloud.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Wheels!

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I know. He flips a switch on the throttle box. There's an ELEC- TRIC WHINE as the LANDING GEAR retract. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Watch the cowl flaps.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I know! And we enter the cloud. Visibility is gone. There's nothing but white blankness. It's like suddenly becoming blind. It's terrifying. There's silence, just the ROAR of the PLANE. Then, abruptly, without warning, another huge B-17 appears right in FRONT of us! We're going to crash into its left wing. There is no way to avoid the collision.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Look out! Luke ducks. Dennis pushes on the control wheel. He does this calmly, without panic. The nose of the Belle suddenly drops down and Virge is thrown off-balance and falls hard to the floor. The other PLANE ROARS directly overhead. When it's clear, Dennis straightnes out the plane. This all happens so fast, it's over before we know it -- but it's hair-raising and an ominous premo- nition of what's to come. Luke comes up from his tuck, amazed they're still in the air. Virge picks himself up then touches his forehead. There's a little gash and he gets blood on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane breaks out above the clouds into dazzling blue sky and bright sun. It's spectacularly beautiful. Another plane comes up on its left: Baby Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke looks out the left window at the left wingman.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Baby Ruth. Who's our right wingman?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Mother and Country.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Swell. The rookie crew. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Luke, take over for a second. Luke puts his hands on the control wheel. Dennis picks up a Thermos from the floor, unscrews the lid and pours hot liquid into the cup. Dennis offers the cup to Virge.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Soup? Virge shakes his head. The cut on his forehead has dried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fierce WIND BLOWS in constantly through the open waist windows. Jack unlashes his gun and strokes it, fondly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Okay, Mona, let's get us a nice little 109 today. We got one, let's do it again.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: Sweet-talking your gun won't help, Jack. Just straight shooting.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Butt out, Gene.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: You know, when I got my two Nazi fighters...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're asking for it! Eugene turns to his side, chuckling. Jack clips him in the back of the legs with his knees, making Eugene crumple and stagger. Jack laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a mess. Les looks around. He closes a locker that was left ajar. He picks up an undershirt lying on the floor, folds it and places it on a bed. Picks up a pair of boots and sets them under another bunk. He starts tucking in the rumpled covers of another bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby Ruth is flying tight on the left and now the brand new plane, Mother and Country, comes up on the right.  112 113 114 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Val is making adjustments to his bombing instruments on the left side of the nose.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Captain, okay if I arm my bombs?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Val yanks out his intercom cord and starts towards the back of the nose. Phil pulls off a class ring from his finger and holds it out.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Val, take this.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
dialogues.text: Phil, you're not going to die.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: VAL
